message_1: Suppose two players are playing a centipede game with 10 rounds where the first player initiates and each round has a potential payout of $10. The second player can either continue the game (with both players receiving $10) or terminate the game (where the first player receives $190 and the second player receives nothing). If both players have perfect information and are rational, at what round would the game typically end?
message_2:
In a centipede game with perfect information and rational players, the game would typically end in the first round. This is because both players will work backwards from the last round to determine their optimal strategy.

In the last round (round 10), the second player has the choice to either continue the game (both players receive $10) or terminate the game (first player receives $190, second player receives nothing). The rational choice for the second player is to terminate the game, as they would receive nothing if they continued.

Knowing this, in the second-to-last round (round 9), the first player has the choice to either continue the game (both players receive $10) or terminate the game (first player receives $190, second player receives nothing). Since the first player knows that the second player will terminate the game in the next round, the rational choice for the first player is to terminate the game in round 9.

However, both players know this logic, so the second player would terminate the game in round 8, the first player in round 7, and so on. This continues all the way back to the first round, where the first player, knowing that the second player would terminate the game in round 2, would choose to terminate the game in the first round.

So, the game would typically end in the first round.
